author: Hardwood-Flooring-Bloomfi
title: Kia's Design Evolution: The Appearances of the Newest Designs
text:
Kia Motors has made substantial strides recently, strengthening its setting as a leading car maker. With a focus on style advancement, Kia has astounded the hearts and minds of auto lovers worldwide. Santa Ana, a vibrant city in The golden state, is no exception to this trend. As the demand for brand-new Kia models in Santa Ana expands, it deserves delving into the looks that have shaped these exceptional vehicles. Join us as we discover the evolution of Kia's design and celebrate the newest designs readily available in the city.
Kia Layout Evolution: Background 101
Kia's style advancement doesn't stop with its present schedule of phenomenal vehicles. The brand has a rich history that showcases its commitment to innovative layout. The earliest Kias were simple and functional automobiles, mirroring the needs and preferences of the time. Nevertheless, as the automobile sector progressed, so did Kia's designs.
In the early 1990s, Kia went into the American market and opened its very first car dealer in the USA. This noted a substantial milestone in the brand name's history as it broadened its existence worldwide. The initial Kia automobiles distributed in the USA were presented with 4 car dealerships in Portland, Oregon. For many years, Kia has actually progressively built a track record for generating trustworthy and budget friendly vehicles.
Among Kia's earliest designs, the Kia Sephia, debuted in 1992 and continued to be in manufacturing until 2003. The Sephia was a compact sedan that offered usefulness and value for cash. While it may not have had the streamlined layout and advanced functions these days's Kia designs, it laid the foundation for the brand's future success.
Another noteworthy design from Kia's earlier years is the Kia Sportage. Launched in 1993, the Sportage was an SUV that caught adventure-seekers' interest. Its tough layout and off-road abilities made it preferred amongst exterior fanatics. Throughout the years, the Sportage has actually advanced and undertaken numerous redesigns, coming to be a trendy and well-rounded SUV in today's Kia lineup.
As Kia continued to innovate and broaden internationally, the brand's designs ended up being a lot more polished and sophisticated. The intro of the Kia Optima in 2000 noted a transforming point in Kia's layout viewpoint. With its sleek and wind resistant designing, the Optima showcased Kia's capacity to create stylish and visually enticing lorries.
In the last few years, Kia's style language has undertaken a significant improvement. Its schedule of the newest designs reflects the brand's dedication to pushing boundaries. The Kia Stinger, a spectacular sports car, takes center stage with its hostile stance and dynamic lines. Created to provide an electrifying efficiency, the Stinger combines power with polished high-end. Its smooth shape and vibrant attributes make it a real head-turner on the streets of Santa Ana.
Another standout in Kia's schedule is the Telluride, a midsize SUV that radiates confidence and presence. With its muscular body and powerful grille, the Telluride makes a vibrant statement any place it goes. Inside, you'll find a sizable and comfy cabin that can fit up to 8 guests, making it ideal for household journeys around Santa Ana.
Kia's commitment to cutting-edge design appears in the upcoming EV6, their very first devoted electric automobile. The EV6 showcases Kia's futuristic vision with its sleek and wind resistant shape. With a focus on sustainability and innovation, the EV6 offers an excellent variety and progressed modern technology, setting a brand-new requirement for electric automobiles in Santa Ana and beyond.
In addition to their latest models, Kia has likewise welcomed the principle of design-led technology. Cooperations with prominent designers such as Peter Schreyer have led to strong and distinctive layout elements that establish Kia in addition to the competitors. The "Tiger Nose" grille, a signature function of Kia lorries, has actually become a legendary symbol of the brand's layout identity.
Revealing the All-New Kia Optima: Redefining Beauty
One of Kia's most highly prepared for releases is the all-new Kia Optima. The Optima exhibits the brand name's commitment to producing captivating layouts by flaunting sleek lines and a wind resistant account. With its bold front grille and striking headlights, this car regulates attention on the streets of Santa Ana. The Optima is a real declaration of luxury and refinement, best for those seeking sophistication in Santa Ana.
The Kia Sorento: Taking On Power and Versatility
The Kia Sorento offers the ideal blend for Santa Ana citizens that hunger for versatility without compromising on design. This midsize SUV stands tall with its muscular exterior and positive position. Its strong front fascia and unique LED headlights make a long lasting impact, while its sizable indoor offers adequate area for passengers and cargo. Whether browsing city roads or exploring the picturesque courses nearby, the Sorento makes sure a thrilling driving experience integrated with the usefulness you require.
Release Your Spirit: The Kia Soul's Distinct Identification
In Santa Ana, uniqueness is commemorated, and the Kia Spirit completely personifies this spirit. With its distinct boxy design and vivid shade choices, the Kia Spirit stands apart on the roads like nothing else. High-mounted taillights and a drifting roofline enhance its vibrant and dynamic look. The Heart's flexibility and undeniable appeal have actually made it a popular selection amongst homeowners trying to find a vehicle that matches their individuality.
Locating The Perfect Kia in Santa Ana
A reliable Kia dealer in Santa Ana supplies lots of new Kia versions to fit every preference. These dealers offer extraordinary customer care and an extensive stock of brand-new and secondhand Kia automobiles, ensuring that discovering the excellent vehicle is a delightful and seamless experience.
Accepting the Future: Kia's Dedication to Innovation
As Kia continues to develop and press the borders of automotive layout, Santa Ana
official source homeowners can anticipate to see even more captivating and ingenious designs in the future. Whether you are seeking a fashionable sedan, a flexible SUV, or an innovative electrical vehicle, Kia has something to match your demands and choices.
So, if one remains in the city and looking for an automobile that incorporates style, performance, and development, look no further than Kia. Get in touch with a Kia dealer in the location and experience the development of Kia's design firsthand. From the brand new Optima to the vibrant Stinger and the upcoming EV6, Kia's visual appeals remain to mesmerize and inspire.

kia maintenance in santa ana today.

author: Louk, Megan C (HSC)
title: OU College of Medicine Appoints New Assistant Deans to Lead Graduate Medical Education Program
text: OKLAHOMA CITY ‚Äî The University of Oklahoma College of Medicine has appointed Kristina Booth, Christina Henson and Mubeen Shakir as assistant deans in its Graduate Medical Education program. The expansion of the leadership team will support advancements in program management, learner assessment and wellness initiatives for residents and fellows. With new Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) requirements on the horizon, the OU College of Medicine is strengthening the connection between the sponsoring institution and its core clinical sites, says Jason Lees, MD, FACS, associate dean of graduate medical education and a general and trauma surgeon at OU Health. ‚ÄúThe role is becoming more expansive, requiring a broader skill set and offering significant opportunities for program development. We are focused on helping directors and coordinators learn best practices from each other and on setting high standards in program quality,‚Äù Lees said. The new assistant deans will help lead the Graduate Medical Education program, supporting the OU College of Medicine. They are: Kristina Booth, MD, FACS, will serve as assistant dean for program development, learner assessment and wellness. An associate professor in the OU Department of Surgery, she has been associate program director for the general surgery residency for six years, where she launched a well-being curriculum that includes policies for lactating residents, resident competitions and social activities. She has led faculty development efforts, introducing innovative evaluation techniques and is nationally recognized for advancing competency-based education through the Society for Improving Medical Professional Learning and the American Board of Surgery‚Äôs Entrustable Professional Activities initiative. She has also contributed to national education projects, presented nationally and mentored associate program directors. Within the OU College of Medicine, she serves on the Academy of Teaching Scholars Executive Committee, is a Student Learning Community Mentor and received the Dewayne Andrews Excellence in GME Teaching award. A native Oklahoman, she earned a bachelor‚Äôs degree at Oklahoma Baptist University, a medical degree and surgical training at OU College of Medicine and a fellowship in colorectal surgery at Texas Health Presbyterian/UT Southwestern. In the new role, she will promote GME best practices, support program development and enhance resident wellness initiatives. Christina Henson, MD, will serve as assistant dean for program assessment and compliance. An associate professor in radiation oncology, she has led the residency program since 2019, achieving full accreditation compliance with zero citations and prioritizing continuous improvement through close collaboration with residents, faculty and coordinators. She is an active member of the OU Graduate Medical Education Committee, serves on the executive committee for the Association of Directors of Radiation Oncology Programs and represents the OU College of Medicine to the Association of American Medical College‚Äôs Council of Faculty and Academic Societies. Beyond her educational leadership, she is a principal investigator on numerous national trials in cancer therapies, has authored over 50 peer-reviewed articles and presented nationally. A native Oklahoman and National Merit Scholar, she graduated summa cum laude from OU and completed a medical degree and radiation oncology training at the OU College of Medicine. In this role, she will help programs establish core assessment metrics, improve accreditation compliance and enhance annual program assessments and reviews. Mubeen Shakir, MD, MPP, will serve as assistant dean for quality and safety. An assistant professor of medicine and chief quality and safety officer for OU Health, he joined OU‚Äôs clinical faculty in 2022, providing primary care and serving as an academic hospitalist. He also has an adjunct appointment at the Hudson College of Public Health. His work has focused on patient safety and harm reduction, including co-leading the Quality Safety Service Symposium, developing a patient safety team and significantly reducing hospital-acquired infections. A native Oklahoman, he studied at OU, earned a Rhodes Scholarship to Oxford, completed his medical degree at Harvard and trained in internal medicine at Massachusetts General. In this new role, he will lead quality and safety curricula for all graduate medical education learners and enhance resident involvement in quality initiatives within OU Health. The position supports mission alignment and strengthens institutional strategy, ensuring full coordination between the sponsoring institution and clinical learning environments. ‚ÄúOur efforts to better assess and grow our programs are crucial as we prepare for new requirements that emphasize alignment and integration between sponsoring institutions and health systems. We aim to connect residents with opportunities for quality improvement, safety initiatives and long-term professional development,‚Äù Lees said. In addition to conferring the Doctor of Medicine degree, the OU College of Medicine offers post graduate residencies and fellowships in numerous specialties and subspecialties. Learn more.

author: Dheshni
title: IDLES POP POP POP Lyrics know the real meaning of IDLES POP POP POP Song lyrics
text: IDLES POP POP POP Lyrics [Verse 1]FreudenfreudeJoy on joy (joy on joy)CheerleaderHappy boy (happy boy)Strong like bullVu-vu-vulnerable (vulnerable)Keep my people upThat's my toolFreudenfreudeHappy boyTop seederLucky koiHeat seeker of a missile smileDon't let pricks take your inch to a mileFreudenfreudeBada bing (bada bing)She's a freight train, manWatch her swingHoly water eyesSoft skinBricks and mortarHorizon begins[Chorus]SunbeamsOh, sunbeamsLike God from your faceSunbeamsOh, sunbeamsLike God from your faceYou might also likeRoyIDLESA GospelIDLESIDEA 01IDLES[Verse 2]Gold sugarHues bright when the salt is purerHold tight (hold tight)Hold me to the bunsen burnerAnd let the wavesCrash in[Chorus]SunbeamsOh, sunbeamsLike God from your faceSunbeamsOh, sunbeamsLike God from your face[Verse 3]FreudenfreudeDopamineDance with time, my boyI'm a fiendWatch the night swing byHold the sceneHold a flame, my boyI'm a dreamFreudenfreudeHot like fireDocile prophetPuts a tune to my smileSend it upLike smoke to the skyDrink my water 'til the river runs dryFreudenfreudeSister's loveHold the swordSo I'm soft to the touchHold the phoneHold the clutchWatch me flyHold a mirrorTo my Mother's crying eyes[Chorus]SunbeamsOh, sunbeamsLike God from your faceSunbeamsOh, sunbeamsLike God from your face IDLES POP POP POP Lyrics Meaning The lyrics of POP POP POP by IDLES explore themes of joy, resilience, and the pursuit of happiness amidst life's challenges. In the verses, the narrator expresses a sense of inner strength and positivity (Joy on joy, Happy boy), juxtaposed with vulnerability (Vu-vu-vulnerable). They emphasize the importance of uplifting others and staying resilient in the face of adversity. References to sunbeams evoke imagery of divine presence and light, symbolizing hope and positivity. IDLES POP POP POP Lyrics Details Album IDLES Release Date 2024 Available on YouTube Music IDLES POP POP POP Lyrics Facts Joy and Resilience: The song celebrates joy (Joy on joy) and resilience amidst challenges, emphasizing the importance of staying positive and uplifting others (Keep my people up).Empowerment and Identity: The lyrics convey a sense of empowerment and self-assurance, with references to being strong yet vulnerable (Strong like bull, vu-vu-vulnerable). The narrator embraces their identity and encourages others to do the same.Imagery and Symbolism: The use of vivid imagery, such as sunbeams likened to a divine presence, and metaphors like freudenfreude (German for joy) and gold sugar, adds depth and symbolism to the song.

title: Misto de ‚Äòfofura‚Äô: Lulu da Pomer√¢nia e Yorkshire t√™m filhotes e beleza encanta
text:
A mistura entre um Lulu da Pomer√¢nia e Yorkshire pode ser um tanto quanto
inusitada. Mas aconteceu para, Adriana Costa, que apresentou lindos e fofos filhotes do casal de cachorros.
Lulu da Pomer√¢nia e Yorkshire deram lindos filhotes
Nascidas em janeiro, os filhotes do Lulu da Pomer√¢nia e Yorkshire chegaram √† vida de Adriana em mar√ßo, por meio da ado√ß√£o, e desde ent√£o √© pura energia, sempre prontas para uma brincadeira.
‚ÄúEu fiquei com duas cachorras, que s√£o f√™meas‚Äù, contou Adriana ao Amo Meu Pet. ‚ÄúDeu tr√™s filhotes, uma ficou com a dona e duas ela doou‚Äù.
Segundo Adriana, a filhote que nasceu com a pelagem preta √© ‚Äúmanhosa com a cara do pai‚Äù, o Lulu.
O Lulu da Pomer√¢nia √© uma
ra√ßa pequena, conhecida por sua pelagem densa e fofa, al√©m de seu comportamento ativo e alerta.
Eles s√£o inteligentes, confiantes e afetuosos, mas tamb√©m podem ser teimosos. S√£o √≥timos c√£es de companhia, sempre atentos ao ambiente e, apesar de seu tamanho, costumam ser corajosos e protetores.
J√° a filhote que nasceu mesclada preta com caramelo, conforme Adriana, √© ‚Äúuma nen√©m terr√≠vel com a cara da m√£e‚Äù, a York.
O Yorkshire Terrier √© uma ra√ßa pequena, com pelagem longa e sedosa, conhecida por sua personalidade corajosa e destemida.
Mistura de ra√ßas
Misturar ra√ßas pode ter riscos significativos, especialmente quando envolve ra√ßas incompat√≠veis em termos de porte. Isso pode resultar em filhotes maiores do que a m√£e, complicando o parto e a gesta√ß√£o.
Para evitar problemas gen√©ticos e de sa√∫de, √© crucial procurar canis certificados pela
Confedera√ß√£o Brasileira de Cinofilia (CBKC) e evitar a reprodu√ß√£o ilegal, que muitas vezes √© motivada apenas pelo lucro e pode levar ao abandono e maus-tratos dos animais.
A orienta√ß√£o de um veterin√°rio √© essencial para realizar cruzamentos de forma segura, garantindo que o porte dos animais e outros fatores sejam considerados para prevenir riscos √† sa√∫de.
A castra√ß√£o √© recomendada para evitar gravidez indesejada e doen√ßas, al√©m de promover a seguran√ßa dos pets com coleiras e equipamentos adequados.

author: Dave Infante
title: Sapporo-Stone Brewing Spent Over $100K Busting Its Union. Here's Why.
text:
Apropos of the Trump administration‚Äôs ongoing anti-constitutional purge in Washington, D.C., shoutout to the federal bureaucracy, man. For decades, it‚Äôs been trendy to shit on this tangle of acronymic entities that gathers data, delivers services, and regulates industry on behalf of the United States‚Äô executive and legislative branches. There are valid critiques to be made of the lowercase-l liberal administrative state, ways it could be improved to function better. One thing it continues to do decently well, though, even as it suffers reckless, illegal swipes from white-supremacist welfare-enjoyer Elon Musk‚Äôs gilded chainsaw, is generate public records.
Amid all the chaos of President Donald Trump‚Äôs trade war, Musk‚Äôs self-serving raid on Social Security et al., and the group chat grotesques of Signalgate, one particular such filing caught my eye. Roughly five months after Sapporo-Stone Brewing (SSB) defeated a union drive at its Richmond, Va., plant, it submitted its required ‚Äúemployer report‚Äù to the Office of Labor-Management Standards (OLMS) earlier this month. The form finally reveals how much money the Japanese macrobrewer‚Äôs American subsidiary spent on the outside consultants ‚Äî ‚Äúpersuaders‚Äù in official parlance, ‚Äúunion-busters‚Äù in labor parlance ‚Äî it hired to help rout its workers bid to collectively bargain with the Teamsters.
The document, known as an LM-10, was filed on March 6, 2025. On it, SSB discloses three payments totalling $114,124 to Government Resources Consultants of America (GRCA), a notoriously aggressive union-avoidance firm, each made between Sept. 25 and Oct. 31, 2024. You can view it in full here.
A box that SSB checked on the LM-10 designates these cash payments were made in exchange for services, arranged starting July 19, 2024, ‚Äúto persuade employees to exercise or not to exercise, or as to the manner of exercising, the right to organize and bargain collectively through representatives of their own choosing.‚Äù
If you‚Äôve never witnessed the grinding hothouse vibe of a workplace in the midst of a union drive, that line item probably sounds fairly anodyne. Ditto, the emailed statement SSB chief executive officer Zach Keeling offered Hop Take through a company spokesperson. ‚ÄúWe gained valuable insights from our Richmond, Va. team during the union campaign last year and we remain committed to partnering directly with our team to build a positive workplace here at Sapporo-Stone,‚Äù he wrote, declining to provide more details on what he described as ‚Äúunion education services‚Äù the brewery purchased from GRCA last summer, as well as my request for a phone interview to discuss the same. Reached by phone, GRCA‚Äôs treasurer, Raymond Rosenbach, also declined to comment.
As longtime labor reporter Dave Jamieson wrote in his award‚Äìwinning 2024 package for HuffPost, ‚ÄúThe Persuaders,‚Äù though, this stuff is anything but anodyne in practice. ‚Äú[P]ersuaders play an undeniable role in suppressing union membership,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúThey help employers craft a playbook against the union. They figure out who supports the union, who opposes it and who sits on the fence. They hold group and one-on-one meetings that sow doubt about what a union can accomplish. Some push the boundaries of what‚Äôs legal and even step over them, according to labor board case files.‚Äù
I‚Äôve seen no evidence that the persuaders SSB hired broke labor laws during their time on retainer. But as Hop Take reported in mid-September 2024, roughly three weeks prior to the National Labor Relations Board-sanctioned election in which Stone‚Äôs workers in Richmond would ultimately reject representation from Teamsters Local 322, GRCA and its subcontractors certainly ran the ‚Äúunion-busting playbook‚Äù against the drive. Workers leaked me the misleading flyers the consultants distributed among brewery employees, and described how they coordinated meetings for anti-union employees to share unverifiable anecdotes about bad individual experiences at other unionized workplaces. In a classic union-busting trick known as ‚Äúthird-partying,‚Äù GRCA also smeared Local 322 as a deceitful interloper ‚Äî even as it was deceitfully interloping itself.
The pressure worked. After collecting signed union cards from around 70 percent of eligible workers at Stone‚Äôs Richmond brewery over the summer, the union lost 32-58. It‚Äôs hard to say how much of the defeat was directly attributable to the six-figures‚Äô worth of face-to-face persuading, and how much was due to SSB‚Äôs procedural gambit with the National Labor Relations Board to include workers at its warehouse outside of town in the voting bloc. (Local 322 acceded to that request, a common management tactic to dilute pro-union voting blocs, to avoid the potentially awkward optics of trying to keep some workers out of the union while encouraging others to vote for it.) But it‚Äôs easy to say how much SSB paid its ‚Äúpersuaders‚Äù to help engineer this outcome, now that the brewer filed its LM-10, and it was a bundle.
‚ÄúThat money should‚Äôve been put towards the workers,‚Äù Local 322‚Äôs Dwayne Johnson tells Hop Take. During the drive, Stone workers told me Richmond‚Äôs rising costs of living were a key reason why they wanted to unionize. That $114,124, Johnson points out, wouldn‚Äôt include the travel costs for the senior SSB executives who came to Richmond late last summer to do ‚Äúpersuading‚Äù of their own during the drive. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs just a small portion of the cost that they used to fend off the union that they could have invested in their employees instead,‚Äù he says.
This is technically true. It‚Äôs also revealing, because $114,124 divided across the 90 workers eligible to vote in last year‚Äôs election works out to less than $1,300 a head. It‚Äôs virtually guaranteed that Local 322 would‚Äôve negotiated a collective bargaining agreement (CBA) that cost SSB more in salaries and benefits in the first year alone. Hell, if SSB spent 10 times more on union busters to smother Local 322 ‚Äî call it an even $1 million ‚Äî that math still probably pencils out. Union busters are expensive, but they‚Äôre cheaper than unions, all the more so given the U.S.‚Äôs laughably loose labor laws, low penalties for violating them, and (now) a Trump-crippled NLRB that will struggle to enforce transgressions. SSB played the hand it was dealt from a deck stacked in its favor.
One more thing. That $114,124 that SSB spent on its GRCA contract is surely less than the Richmond brewery‚Äôs labor costs would‚Äôve been under a Teamster CBA. But it‚Äôs hardly a drop in the bucket barrel compared to the $91 million impairment charge Sapporo Holdings (SSB‚Äôs Japanese parent company) recently took on Stone itself, which it acquired for $165 million in 2022. We talked about this a bit the other day. Sapporo‚Äôs recently minted largest shareholder is ripshit mad about it, accusing the firm of ‚Äúdestroy[ing] shareholder capital through acquisition[s]‚Äù like Anchor Brewing Co., Sleeman Breweries, and Stone; SSB tells Hop Take in a statement that despite the near-nine-figure write-down, it grew revenues for Stone and Sapporo last year and is set up well for the future.
Time will tell on that. But one conclusion you could draw right now is that this company‚Äôs executives have wasted a lot of money on bets that have yet to pay off. This bears on the question of why SSB splashed out on pricey consultants to defeat the drive in Richmond last summer, rather than bet on itself by investing in its workforce. I suspect the answer is less to save money than to maintain unilateral control over its newly upgraded plant in the River City.
In this, SSB follows a brewing-industry example established by August Busch III during the 100-day Teamster strike on the macrobrewer‚Äôs St. Louis plant back in 1976. The stoppage cost A-B some $30 million in lost sales, but ‚ÄúThe Chief‚Äù won something more valuable: continued unilateral control over the family‚Äôs brewery. ‚ÄúThey wanted written into the contract that they would have the right to approve or disapprove any changes in production before we could implement them,‚Äù he said, as captured in William Knoedelseder‚Äôs ‚ÄúBitter Brew.‚Äù Keeping that out of the eventual CBA was worth $30 million, if not more, to arguably the best brewing boss of his ‚Äî or any ‚Äî era.
The workers at Stone‚Äôs Richmond brewery never got that far. And those days are long gone for both the American brewing industry and organized labor. But it helps to wrap your head around why SSB would spend $114,124 to stop a union drive even as it was en route to wiping almost an order of magnitude more value off its books. Money spent to bust a union is money well spent. Money spent on a craft brewery that turns out to be worth less than half as much after less than three years at the helm? That‚Äôs just the bosses‚Äô call, man.
ü§Ø Hop-ocalypse Now
The United States imports an enormous amount of barley from Canada, but here‚Äôs the thing ‚Äî it also exports an enormous amount of malt to Mexico. In fact, our neighbors to the north sell us more of the crop than any other country, and our neighbors to the south buy more of the semi-finished product than any other country. (Canada also buys a bunch of barley from this country. Global trade: it‚Äôs complicated!) Thanks to President Donald Trump‚Äôs destructive, pointless trade war, both those relationships are in unprecedented jeopardy, and American farmers are feeling the squeeze. ‚ÄúWe are scared almost to death about tariffs,‚Äù Montana Grain Growers Association vice president Steve Sheffels recently told Reuters. More like Malt-pocalypse Now, amirite?! (Sorry, I know this is serious.)
üìà Ups‚Ä¶
Anderson Valley Brewing Co., one of California‚Äôs oldest still-operating craft breweries, has been sold to a new, local owner‚Ä¶ Roughly a year and a half after acquiring Anheuser-Busch InBev‚Äôs defunct energy-drink brand, Tilray Brands will return Hi*Ball to Whole Foods‚Äô shelves‚Ä¶ The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau quietly withdrew its proposed rules for ingredient labeling last week, considered a potentially existential burden by craft brewers‚Ä¶
üìâ ‚Ä¶and downs
Anheuser-Busch InBev pulled out of its St. Louis Pride sponsorship after 30 years of support‚Ä¶ The Teamsters called on Trump to levy tariffs on ‚Äúlow-road Mexican companies‚Äù that export beer stateside, as though that would help domestics somehow‚Ä¶ Bill Renspie, the chief customer officer of Constellation Brands‚Äô Beer Division, stepped down suddenly last week after two decades at the firm‚Ä¶ That, as Citi [downgraded](https://beerinsights.com/archive-article/55241) Constellation‚Äôs stock in the face of Trump‚Äôs trade war‚Ä¶ Man, only six Major League Baseball teams have [signed on](https://vinepair.com/booze-news/mlb-stadiums-changing-domestic-beer-to-american-abi/) to Anheuser-Busch InBev‚Äôs ‚ÄúAmerican, not domestic‚Äù messaging, outta 30‚Ä¶
This story is a part of [VP Pro](https://vinepair.com/business-of-drinks/), our free platform and newsletter for drinks industry professionals, covering wine, beer, liquor, and beyond. [Sign up for VP Pro now!](https://vinepair.com/vp-pro-join/)

organizations.name: The Alcohol and Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau

author: Nouvelles
title: En M√©diterran√©e, attendez-vous √† des inondations plus fr√©quentes. Le m√©t√©orologue explique les conditions m√©t√©orologiques extr√™mes en Espagne ‚Äî Denn√≠k N
text:
2024-11-01 20:43:00
Plus de deux cents personnes sont mortes dans ce qui est probablement l‚Äôinondation la plus meurtri√®re de l‚Äôhistoire moderne de l‚ÄôEspagne. Des pluies torrentielles ont frapp√© la r√©gion orientale de Valence.
La pluie a emport√© les ponts, les voitures et les immeubles. De nombreuses personnes sont mortes apr√®s avoir √©t√© coinc√©es dans des voitures. ‚ÄúDes quantit√©s extr√™mement importantes de pr√©cipitations sont tomb√©es en tr√®s peu de temps‚Äù, explique Michal ≈Ω√°k, m√©t√©orologue et professeur d‚Äôuniversit√©.
